expanded_description: This section introduces the fundamental concepts of motion in one dimension, including reference points, frames of reference, and the basic vocabulary used to describe how objects move. Understanding these foundations is essential for analyzing motion quantitatively.

core_concept.principle: Motion is the change in an object's position relative to a reference point over time. Describing motion requires a frame of reference and an understanding of distance, displacement, speed, velocity, and acceleration.
core_concept.explanation: Everything in the universe is in motion, but motion can only be described relative to something else. A car moves relative to the road, the Earth moves relative to the Sun, and the Sun moves relative to the galaxy. Choosing a reference point allows us to measure and describe motion meaningfully.

image.alt: Diagram showing different reference points for describing motion: car moving past tree, Earth orbiting Sun
image.caption: Motion is always described relative to a chosen reference point

sections.introduction: When we describe motion, we answer questions like: Where is it? Where is it going? How fast is it moving? Is it speeding up or slowing down? These questions require specific vocabulary and concepts.

key_concept.definition: Motion is the change in an object's position over time. To describe motion completely, we need to specify position, time, and how position changes with time.
key_concept.context: The language of motion includes terms like distance, displacement, speed, velocity, and acceleration. Each term has a precise meaning in physics that may differ from everyday usage.

principles.statement: There is no absolute frame of reference. All motion is described relative to some chosen reference point.
principles.application: When describing motion, always specify or imply what you're measuring relative to. A book on a table is at rest relative to the table but moving relative to the Sun.
principles.example: A passenger on a train walking forward has a different velocity relative to the train than relative to the ground. Both descriptions are correct - they just use different reference frames.
principles.analogy: Like giving directions: "3 blocks north of the school" uses the school as a reference point. Without that reference, the directions are meaningless.

principles.statement: Motion is about change over time. A snapshot showing position alone cannot tell us about motion.
principles.application: To determine if something is moving, we need at least two position measurements at different times.
principles.example: A photograph of a car shows its position at an instant. Two photographs taken at different times reveal whether it moved and how fast.

principles.statement: Physics describes motion quantitatively using measurable quantities like position, time, velocity, and acceleration.
principles.application: Instead of saying "the car is moving fast," we say "the car's velocity is 25 m/s east."
principles.example: A complete description of motion might be: "At t = 0 s, the object was at position x = 10 m. At t = 5 s, it was at x = 35 m, moving with constant velocity of 5 m/s."

classifications.value: Different categories of motion based on path and rate
characteristics: Translational motion: object moves from one point to another
Rotational motion: object spins around an axis
Periodic motion: motion repeats in regular intervals
classifications.behavior: One-dimensional motion (along a straight line) is the simplest type and the foundation for understanding more complex motion. In 1D, we only need one coordinate (usually x) to specify position.

examples.explanation: A train moving along a straight track - position can be described by a single number (distance from station).
A ball thrown upward at an angle - requires both x and y coordinates.
A merry-go-round spinning - points move in circles.
A pendulum swinging back and forth - motion repeats.

image.alt: Illustrations showing different types of motion: linear, projectile, rotational, periodic
image.caption: Motion can be classified by path and pattern

sections.section_title: Reference Points and Frames of Reference
sections.introduction: A frame of reference is a coordinate system used to describe motion. The choice of reference frame affects the measured position, velocity, and even the observed path of an object.

key_concept.definition: A frame of reference is a set of coordinates (like x, y, z axes) and a clock used to measure position and time. It defines the point from which measurements are made.
key_concept.context: Different observers in different frames of reference may measure different positions and velocities for the same object. All descriptions are valid within their own frame.

principles.statement: A reference point is a fixed location (often called the origin) from which positions are measured.
principles.application: Decide where x = 0 is. Common choices: starting point, ground level, a stationary object.
principles.example: In a race, we might set the starting line as x = 0. Positions ahead are positive, behind are negative.

principles.statement: We need a consistent sign convention to indicate direction along a line.
principles.application: Choose one direction as positive (usually right, up, or forward) and the opposite as negative.
principles.example: If east is positive, then a position of -50 m means 50 m west of the origin.

principles.statement: An object's motion appears different from different reference frames.
principles.application: When solving problems, identify your frame of reference and stick with it consistently.
principles.example: To a person standing on the ground, a falling ball moves straight down. To a person in a moving car, the same ball follows a curved path.

worked_examples.title: Reference Frames
worked_examples.problem: A train moves east at 20 m/s relative to the ground. A passenger walks toward the front of the train at 2 m/s relative to the train. What is the passenger's velocity relative to the ground?

step_by_step.explanation: We have two frames: ground frame and train frame. The passenger's motion relative to train is given; we want it relative to ground.
$v_{pg} = v_{pt} + v_{tg}$ where pg = passenger relative to ground, pt = passenger relative to train, tg = train relative to ground.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Velocities add when moving between reference frames. The passenger's motion relative to ground is the sum of motion relative to train and train's motion relative to ground.

image.alt: Diagram showing different reference frames: ground observer and moving train observer
image.caption: Motion appears differently from different reference frames

sections.introduction: To describe motion completely, we need several quantities: position tells us where; time tells us when; displacement tells us how far and in what direction; velocity tells us how fast and in what direction; acceleration tells us how velocity is changing.

key_concept.definition: The fundamental quantities in kinematics are position (x), time (t), displacement ($\Delta x$), velocity (v), and acceleration (a). Each builds on the previous to give a complete description of motion.
key_concept.context: These quantities are interconnected: velocity is the rate of change of position; acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. Understanding these relationships is key to analyzing motion.

characteristics: Position (x): where an object is located relative to origin
Time (t): when an observation is made
Both are scalars with sign conventions
classifications.behavior: Position requires a reference point (origin) and a sign convention. Time is usually measured from some starting moment (t = 0). Together, they give the coordinates of an event.

examples.explanation: x = 15 m means 15 m in the positive direction from the origin.
t = 3 s means 3 seconds after we started our clock.

characteristics: Can be positive, negative, or zero
classifications.behavior: Displacement measures how far and in what direction an object has moved from start to finish. It depends only on initial and final positions, not on the path taken.

examples.explanation: Moving from x = 2 m to x = 8 m: $\Delta x = 8 - 2 = +6$ m
Moving from x = 8 m to x = 2 m: $\Delta x = 2 - 8 = -6$ m

characteristics: Can be positive, negative, or zero
classifications.behavior: Velocity tells how fast position is changing and in what direction. Average velocity uses total displacement over total time. Instantaneous velocity is velocity at a specific instant.

examples.explanation: Displacement 50 m east in 10 s: $v_{avg} = 5$ m/s east

characteristics: Can be positive, negative, or zero
classifications.behavior: Acceleration tells how fast velocity is changing. Positive acceleration means velocity is increasing in the positive direction; negative acceleration (deceleration) means velocity is decreasing or increasing in the negative direction.

examples.explanation: Velocity changes from 0 to 10 m/s east in 5 s: $a = 2$ m/s² east
Velocity changes from 10 m/s east to 0 in 5 s: $a = -2$ m/s² east

image.alt: Diagram showing relationships between position, displacement, velocity, and acceleration
image.caption: Kinematics quantities build on each other: velocity is rate of change of position; acceleration is rate of change of velocity

sections.introduction: In one-dimensional motion, we use positive and negative signs to indicate direction. Establishing a consistent sign convention is essential for correct problem-solving.

key_concept.definition: A sign convention is a rule that assigns positive and negative values to directions along the chosen axis. All vector quantities (position, displacement, velocity, acceleration) then have signs indicating their direction.
key_concept.context: The sign convention is arbitrary - you can choose either direction as positive. The key is to be consistent throughout the entire problem.

principles.statement: Decide at the beginning which direction is positive, and use that convention for all quantities in the problem.
principles.application: Write down your convention: "Let east (or right, or up) be positive." Then all vectors pointing that way are positive; opposite directions are negative.
principles.example: If up is positive, a velocity of -10 m/s means 10 m/s downward.

principles.statement: The sign of a vector quantity tells its direction relative to your chosen positive direction.
principles.application: When reading a problem, pay attention to words like east/west, up/down, right/left, forward/backward. Translate these into signs.
principles.example: "A car travels west at 20 m/s" with east positive means v = -20 m/s.

principles.statement: The sign of acceleration depends on direction of change, not direction of motion. An object can have positive acceleration while slowing down if it's moving in the negative direction.
principles.application: Think: Is velocity becoming more positive or more negative?
principles.example: A car moving west (- direction) that slows down has positive acceleration (since its velocity becomes less negative).

worked_examples.title: Sign Convention Practice
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown upward from ground level. Using up as positive, determine the signs of displacement, velocity, and acceleration at: (a) while rising, (b) at the peak, (c) while falling.

step_by_step.explanation: Up is positive. Down is negative.
Displacement: above start, so positive. Velocity: moving up, so positive. Acceleration: gravity always pulls down, so acceleration is negative throughout the entire motion.
Displacement: positive (still above start). Velocity: zero. Acceleration: still negative.
Displacement: still positive until passing start. Velocity: moving down, so negative. Acceleration: still negative.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Rising: $\Delta x > 0$, $v > 0$, $a < 0$ (b) Peak: $\Delta x > 0$, $v = 0$, $a < 0$ (c) Falling: $\Delta x > 0$ (until ground), $v < 0$, $a < 0$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Acceleration due to gravity is constant and downward regardless of motion direction. Sign conventions must be applied consistently.

image.alt: Number line showing positive and negative directions with examples
image.caption: Choose a positive direction and use signs consistently for all vectors

summary: Introduction to motion establishes the foundational concepts for kinematics. Motion is the change in position over time relative to a reference point. All motion is relative - there is no absolute frame of reference. A frame of reference includes a coordinate system (with an origin and sign convention) and a clock. In one-dimensional motion, we use a single axis (usually x) and assign positive and negative signs to indicate direction. The key quantities for describing motion are: position (x, where an object is located), time (t, when an observation is made), displacement ($\Delta x = x_f - x_i$, change in position), velocity ($v_{avg} = \Delta x/\Delta t$, rate of change of position), and acceleration ($a_{avg} = \Delta v/\Delta t$, rate of change of velocity). Each quantity builds on the previous to give a complete description. Sign conventions must be established at the beginning of a problem and applied consistently to all vector quantities. Understanding these foundations is essential for analyzing motion quantitatively using graphs and equations in the following sections.
